title: Scottish Election Study 2007
abstractText:
The main purpose of this research project is to explain the behaviour of the Scottish electorate on polling day in May 2007. It is centred on a two-wave panel survey, with a representative sample of Scottish voters questioned both before and after polling day. The survey will be conducted over the internet, by YouGov. The post-election questionnaire will replicate the ‘election study’ component of the Scottish Social Attitudes 2007 face-to-face questionnaire. This allows for comparison of the results generated by an internet and an interview survey, a methodological innovation offering large potential efficiency gains in the future, given the much lower costs of web-based data collection.

The main substantive theme of the study is the complexity of the tasks facing voters in these (concurrent Holyrood and local council) elections. One feature is a test of the theory of ‘valence politics’ – voting according to government performance/competence rather than specific issue/ideological stances – in the Scottish context, in which voters have to attribute responsibility for performance both vertically (across levels of government) and horizontally (between coalition partners).  Another focus is the voters’ coalition preferences, and the accuracy of their perceptions of the parties’ preferences. Clearly it is also essential to examine whether voters understand and can sensibly operate within the different electoral systems employed in 2007
